Graphical abstract WO3- x with oxygen vacancy is prepared by a facile hydrothermal reduction strategy. WO3- x exhibits fast reaction kinetics and robust structural stability, endowing the fuel-free bio-photoelectrochemical cell with high power output and long-term stability. Bio-photoelectrochemical cells (BPECs) can further expand the use of conventional biofuel cells for renewable energy, but the poor stability of the photoelectrode still hinders their practical application. Herein, a BPEC capable of long-term operating in a fuel-free model is fabricated by WO3- x photoanode with oxygen vacancy (Ov) and bilirubin oxidase catalyzed biocathode. The construction of Ov on the WO3 surface significantly suppresses the dissolution of W species into the electrolyte, and improves the charge separation efficiency and the reaction kinetics during the photoelectrochemical oxygen evolution process, thus enhancing the stability and power output performance of the BPEC. As a result, the assembled BPEC can output an open circuit voltage of 0.81 V and deliver a maximum output power of up to 283 μW cm−2. Impressively, the BPECs maintain 97% of their original power after 36000 s of consecutive discharge under an enclosed environment. This fuel-free BPEC based on a robust WO3- x photoanode shows excellent promise for accurate application. Keywords WO3 Oxygen vacancy Oxygen reduction reaction Fuel-free Bio-photoelectrochemical cell 1 Introduction Bio-photoelectrochemical cells (BPECs) are a kind of energy conversion devices that integrate two types of electrode reactions, bioelectrocatalysis and photocatalysis [1], which achieve the simultaneous conversion of solar and chemical energies to electricity [2]. BPECs are promising for a wide range of energy conversion applications owing to their merits of being clean, sustainability and environmental benign. However, the low power output resulting from low charge separation efficiency [3], sluggish reaction kinetics [4], and poor stability caused by the photocorrosion of the photoelectrode limit the further development and practical application of the BPECs [5]. The construction of high-performance BPECs requires advanced photocatalytic materials with proper band-gap for light absorption and robust structure stability [6]. Using n-type semiconductor as the photoanode of a BPEC provides a lower open-circuit potential (OCP) at the anode, which enables high output voltage of the BPECs. Among these, the n-type semiconductor WO3 is considered a unique material due to its relatively small band gap energy (2.8 eV), the ability to absorb an extensive range of the visible spectrum, and the advantage of highly oxidative photogenerated holes for visible-light-driven water oxidation [7]. However, WO3 suffers from slow interfacial photogenerated hole migration rates and fast recombination of photogenerated hole-electron pairs, resulting in sluggish reaction kinetics [8]. In addition, the photocorrosion of WO3 upon illumination leads to the dissolution of W species into the electrolyte, which deteriorates the operation stability of the electrode [9]. Introducing oxygen vacancy (Ov) into WO3 has been proven to be an effective strategy for improving the stability of WO3 [10]. Li et al. [11] used a high-temperature thermal annealing procedure to reduce WO3 for the synthesis of defective WO3- x under H2 atmosphere. The obtained WO3- x maintained a stable water oxidation reaction for at least 7 h without loss of photoactivity. Despite the enhanced operation stability, the entire reaction process for the synthesis of WO3- x needs to be maintained at high temperatures (250–500 °C), and H2 leakage during the annealing procedure could bring security risks. It has been shown that the amount and position of Ov present in WO3 play a significant role in determining the performance of the WO3 photoelectrode [12]. Surface Ov can significantly improve the separation efficiency of the charge carriers by migrating the valence band edge of WO3 to a more hostile position [13]. However, too much Ov in the bulk WO3 phase acts as a trap site for the recombination of photogenerated carriers, failing to achieve the desired photogenerated current. The bulk phase Ov shows a limited ability to suppress the recombination of the photogenerated hole-electron pairs by turning WO3 into a narrower band gap material [14]. Therefore, exploring novel approaches with merits of energy efficiency, high safety, and controllable synthesis of surface Ov is of great significance for developing high-performance WO3-based BPECs. Herein, a facile one-step hydrothermal reduction strategy is proposed for controllable synthesis of WO3 with desired surface Ov (denoted as WO3-x ). The WO3- x photoelectrode exhibits a significantly higher photocatalytic current and more stable operation time than that of the pristine WO3. Consequently, a novel type of BPECs based on the water/oxygen circulation system is assembled using WO3- x /fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) as photoanode and bilirubin oxidase (BOD), protoporphyrin IX (PIX), carbon nanotubes (CNTs)-functionalized carbon cloth (CC) as biocathode (denoted as BOD/PIX/CNTs/CC), as shown in Scheme. 1 . In this BPEC, photogenerated holes on the WO3- x surface catalyze the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) upon illumination. The produced O2 is then diffused to the biocathode, where BOD accepts the photogenerated electrons from the photoanode and catalyzes the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), thus forming a closed loop of the water/oxygen circulation to convert light and chemical energies into electricity in a fuel-free pattern. The as-fabricated BPECs can deliver an open circuit voltage of 0.81 V and a maximum power density of up to 283 μW cm−2. Sealing tests successfully demonstrate that the water/oxygen circulation can be completed with outstanding output power and storage stability. Impressively, the BPECs exhibit superior operational stability, with 97% of their original power remaining after 36000 s of consecutive discharge under an enclosed environment, which can be attributed to the enhanced reaction kinetics and structural stability due to the rationally designed Ov on the WO3- x surface. Therefore, the WO3- x synthesized in this work is a promising photoanode material applied for OER in BPECs. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents and materials (NH4)10[H2W12O4] xH2O was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. HCl (37%), H2SO4 (98%), H3PO4 (85%), acetone (99.5%), H2O2 (30%), ethylene glycol (99%), anhydrous ethanol (99.7%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., ltd. FTO glasses were obtained from South China Science & Technology Co., ltd. BOD was acquired from Shanghaiyuanye Bio-Technology Co., ltd. BOD solution (10 mg mL−1) was prepared by dissolving the powder in 0.1 M Tris-PBS (pH 7.0). PIX and Nafion 117 solution were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. CNTs and ethylene glycol (EG, 99.5%) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., ltd. All chemicals were of analytical grade and used as received without further purification. Milli-Q ultrapure water (18.2 MΩ cm) was used throughout the preparation of the electrolyte solution, and all of the experiments were performed at room temperature. 2.2 Instrumentation X-ray diffractometer (XRD) was chosen to study the crystal structure of the photoanode material, with data manufactured from an XRD-6100 (Rigaku, Japan). Scanning electron microscope (SEM) was used to characterize the microscopic morphology of the prepared samples (HITACHI S-4800 machine from Hitachi, Japan). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was chosen to reflect the amount of Ov on the surface of the prepared material with HITACHI S-4800 (Kratos, Japan). Transmission electron microscope (TEM) was performed on a JEOL JEM-2100 microscope operating at 300 kV. The UV-vis absorption spectra were obtained from UV-3600 (Shimadzu, Japan). Before and after the amperometric measurement, the electrolyte was analyzed using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS, ICAP RQ). The Ov of WO3-x was analyzed by electron paramagnetic resonance (A300-10/12 from Burker, Germany). 2.3 Preparation of WO3- x /FTO photoanode The preparation process of WO3- x /FTO photoanodes is shown in (Fig. 1 a). (NH4)10[H2W12O4] xH2O was chosen as the source of tungsten, and WO3 nanorods were grown on FTO glass substrates by hydrothermal method [15], followed by hydrothermal treatment in EG solution to form Ov on the WO3 surface through the reducing properties of EG [16]. Due to the special hydrogen bonding structure of EG and the moderate reducing properties under appropriate thermal conditions, the diagonal oxygens were trapped directly from the surface, leaving Ov. The specific reaction equation was shown in the following Eq. (1). (1) 2 W O 3 + x C 2 H 6 O 2 → H y d r o t h e r m a l x C 2 H 2 O 2 + 2 W O 3 - x + 2 x H 2 O In order to estimate the performance of photoanode and biocathode, the electrochemical and photoelectrochemical measurements were performed using a typical three-electrode cell in which photoanode or biocathode served as the working electrode, Pt foil (1 cm2) was used as the counter electrode. Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl) was used as the reference electrode. The electrochemical and photoelectrochemical experiments were conducted on a CHI660E Electrochemical Workstation (Shanghai Chenhua Instruments Co., ltd., China). All light conditions in the experiment were provided by a 300 W xenon lamp equipped with AM 1.5 G analogue solar filters, and the light intensity at the surface of the electrode was 100 mW cm−2. 2.4 Preparation of BOD/PIX/CNTs biocathode The BOD-modified biocathodes were prepared by an induced orientation method using CNTs as the supporting material and PIX as the orientation inducer according to our previous work [17]. The procedure was as follows: 10 mg of CNTs was ultrasonically dispersed in 4 mL of isopropanol/water (1:3 v/v) to produce CNTs dispersion. The glassy carbon electrodes (GCE, 3 mm in diameter) were polished on Al2O3 slurry (involving three different particle sizes, 1.0, 0.3 and 0.05 μm) to remove surface contaminants, followed by ultrasonication in deionized water, 1 M H2SO4, anhydrous ethanol and deionized water in sequence for 1 min, and finally dried under an infrared lamp. 9 μL of the dispersion was added to GCE. The electrodes were dried and then immersed in a solution of N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) containing 0.5 mM PPIX for 1 h. Afterward, the electrode was rinsed with deionised water to remove unabsorbed PPIX and excess NMP and dried under an infrared lamp. 6 μL of BOD solution (10 mg mL−1 containing 0.5% Nafion solution) was added dropwise to the CNTs-modified GCE and stored in a refrigerator at 4 °C until the water was dried (indicated as BOD/PPIX/CNTs). As a control experiment, the same dose of BOD solution was added dropwise to the CNTs-modified GCE without the addition of PPIX and stored in a refrigerator at 4 °C (denoted as BOD/CNTs). To investigate the ORR performance of commercial Pt/C (10 wt%), Pt/C-modified GCE was prepared as follows: 10 mg of commercial Pt/C was ultrasonically dispersed in 1 mL of isopropanol/water (1:3 v/v) to produce a Pt/C dispersion (containing 0.5% Nafion). 6 μL of Pt/C dispersion was added dropwise on GCE and stored in a refrigerator at 4 °C until the electrode was dried (labeled as 10 wt% Pt/C). 2.5 Fabrication and performance evaluation of BPECs The BPECs were fabricated in one-chamber quartz electrochemical cell using WO3- x /FTO as the photoanode and BOD/PIX/CNTs/CC as the biocathode. 0.1 M Tris-PBS (pH 7.0) was used as the electrolyte. To evaluate the performance of BPECs, a 300 W Xe lamp (PLS-SXE 300D, Beijing Perfectlight, China) with an AM 1.5 G filter was used as a light source. The light intensity was calibrated to ca. 100 mW cm−2 using a Photoradiometer (PL-MW 2000, Beijing Perfect light, China). The automatic shielding/unshielded of light in the measurements as chopped illumination was controlled using a Shutter Controller (PFS40A, Beijing Perfect light, China). The power output performance of the BPECs was evaluated using linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) from OCP of the cell to 0 V vs. Ag/AgCl at a scan rate of 1.0 mV s−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the WO3- x photoanode To investigate the optimal hydrothermal time for WO3, materials obtained under different hydrothermal times were selected for SEM characterization. As shown in Fig. S1, the WO3 shows a remarkably smooth rod-like structure with many gaps between the rods, which allows the electrolyte to penetrate into the resulting gaps and increases the area of WO3 available for the catalytic reaction. In contrast, the materials obtained from 1 h and 2 h of hydrothermal process exhibit more finely ground rods with a more dense composition. The cross-section in the inset shows a change in thickness from 417 nm to 859 nm. With the increase of hydrothermal time to 3 h and 4 h, the morphologies of the WO3 change from fine rods to a more pronounced rod-like structure (Fig. S1c and d), and the thickness of the samples increases from 1.32 μm to 1.69 μm. An increase in the diameter of the rod with a constant material thickness would increase the electron diffusion path, which may lead to a decrease in the catalytic current. Fig. 1(b) presents the XRD spectra of WO3 and WO3- x , which shows four distinct characteristic diffraction peaks located at 23.3°, 23.7°, 24.5°, and 34.5°, corresponding to the monoclinic WO3 (PDF#43–1035). After hydrothermal treatment with EG, the diffraction peaks of the treated WO3- x are similar to those of WO3, suggesting that hydrothermal treatment does not destroy the crystal structure of WO3. Fig. S2 shows SEM images of WO3 and WO3- x . Clearly, the WO3- x obtained after the EG thermal reduction still maintains a rod-like and non-adhesive structure, which is consistent with the untreated WO3. From the above characterization, the EG treatment does not damage the original structure of WO3. The thickness of WO3- x -6 h, WO3- x -9 h and WO3- x -12 h photoanodes was investigated by SEM. As shown in Fig. S3, the thickness of the electrodes does not change significantly with hydrothermal time in ethylene glycol. The visible light absorption capacity of WO3 nanorods and EG-modified WO3- x nanorods under different treatment times was investigated. From Fig. 1(c), the absorption intensities of WO3- x -6 h, WO3- x -9 h, and WO3- x -12 h are negligible compared to pristine WO3, and the absorption band edges of all the prepared samples are uniformly located at around 420 nm and 490 nm, demonstrating that the EG reduction does not change the response of WO3 to light. UV-vis diffuse reflectance absorption spectrum was used to investigate whether the EG treatment process affects the forbidden band width of WO3. The Tauc curve (Fig. 1d), which represents the band gap, is obtained by plotting (αhυ)1/2 against hυ (Equation S1) [18]. WO3 shows an absorption edge at 420 nm which can be estimated at a band gap energy of 2.67 eV, and the absorption edge at approximately 490 nm corresponds to a band gap energy of 2.77 eV. A displacement of the band gap of the WO3- x nanosheets can be clearly observed, which can be attributed to the quantum confinement effect of the nanomaterials [19]. Impressively, the WO3- x nanosheets show a very large absorption tail, which covers almost the entire visible region (i.e. 500–800 nm) [20]. This result can be attributed to the formation of surface Ov on the photocatalyst, according to the reference that leads to a broad and intense surface plasmon resonance (SPR) absorption in the visible region. The WO3- x nanorods obtained with different treatment time show no change in the original forbidden bandwidth, indicating that the changes in the photoelectrochemical properties of WO3 in this experiment are not directly related to the change in the strength of the light absorption properties of the material. The surface chemical state of pristine WO3 and WO3- x nanorods was investigated by XPS, as shown in Fig. 1(e). W and O elements can be detected in the samples. From the W 4f XPS spectra of the samples (Fig. 1f), as hydrothermal time increases, the binding energy of W 4f shifts to lower binding energies, indicating a decreased chemical state in W species and an increase in electron density, forming defective WO3- x materials [21]. W 4f XPS spectra of the samples were deconvoluted and are shown in Fig. S4. The W 4f spectra from the pristine WO3 samples show broad peaks corresponding to the characteristic W 4f5 /2 and W 4f 7/2 peaks of WO3. The W 4f of pristine WO3 can be deconvoluted into two peaks corresponding to the typical binding energies of the W6+ oxidation state (centered at 37.7 and 35.5 eV) and the W5+ oxidation state (centered at 37.2 and 34.3 eV) [22], respectively. By deconvoluting the XPS peak of W 4f, the W5+ content of pristine WO3 was estimated to be 2.7%, indicating the presence of surface Ov, which is consistent with previous reports. After the introduction of Ov into the WO3, the content of W5+ in the WO3- x photoanodes is gradually increased from 6.38% in WO3 to 16.25% in WO3- x -6 h, 18.34% in WO3- x -9 h, and 19.95% in WO3- x -12 h. The presence of W5+ indicates the presence of Ov on the surface of WO3- x . Therefore, the oxidation state of the element W in WO3 and WO3- x is mainly W6+, partial W5+ can be detected in both WO3 and WO3- x [23]. To further elucidate the chemical state of WO3 before and after the introduction of Ov, XPS spectra of pristine WO3, WO3- x -6 h, WO3- x -9 h and WO3- x -12 h samples were tested, which confirms the presence of W and O. Meanwhile, the elemental oxygen peaked based on O 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 1g). O 1s XPS spectra of the samples were deconvoluted. As shown in Fig. S5, all samples show distinct O 1s peaks at 531.4 and 530.2 eV [8], which can be attributed to O atoms near the surface Ov and lattice oxygen in the metal oxides, respectively. A clear hierarchy in the content of surface Ov for WO3- x -12 h (47.9%) > WO3- x -9 h (42.1%) > WO3- x -6 h (36.1%) > WO3 (19.1%) is observed. Of note, as the hydrothermal time increases, more unpaired electrons are captured by Ov, and the amount of Ov can be regulated by the hydrothermal time. Therefore, the introduction of Ov in WO3 via ethylene glycol thermal reduction is proved to be an effective solution. The binding energies for the WO3- x migrate towards the higher binding energies, with the highest value (corresponding to 530.6 eV) being reached for the WO3-x -12 h. This is due to the increased proportion of Ov within the material [24], indicating that increasing the hydrothermal time could increase the content of Ov. TEM was used to characterize the morphologies of the WO3- x samples. Fig. 2 (a) shows TEM of WO3- x nanorods with a diameter of ca. 180 nm, which is consistent with the SEM results (Fig. S1b). A local area of the nanorods was selected to obtain the HRTEM image (Fig. 2b), and the lattice stripe is found to be 0.383 nm, which could match the d-spacing value of the (002) plane. Note that the outer edge region of around 1.8 nm in the WO3- x nanorods shows an amorphous form, which could be assigned to the presence of Ov on the surface of WO3- x [25]. Fig. 2(c) shows the EDS element mapping of WO3- x , revealing the uniform distribution of W and O elements throughout the WO3- x nanorod. As can be seen from the Table S1 , the atomic percentage of W and O is determined to be 2.86:1. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was utilized further to prove the presence of Ov defects within WO3- x [26]. As shown in Fig. 2(e), an increase in the defect signal at g = 2.002 can be detected in the WO3- x . The presence of Ov traps electrons to absorb resonances and the defective WO3 photoanode has a g value of about 2.00, which is consistent with previous reports [27]. The above characterizations confirm that the content of Ov defects in the WO3- x can be increased by a facile hydrothermal treatment using EG as a reduction agent. 3.2 Photoelectrochemical performance of the WO3- x photoanode The photoelectrochemical performances of pristine WO3/FTO were investigated using LSV in 0.1 M Tris-PBS under AM 1.5 G irradiation. Fig. S6 shows that no current can be detected in the absence of light, and all samples have a rapid photo-response under light irradiation, indicating that photogenerated charge carriers drive the OER. The current densities of the pristine WO3/FTO samples increase with the increase of hydrothermal time from 1 h to 3 h, while further increasing the hydrothermal time leads to a decrease in current density. WO3 obtained after 3 h of hydrothermal treatment has the highest photocurrent density value of 1.08 mA cm−2 (0.6 V vs. Ag/AgCl) among the samples. This suggests that as the hydrothermal time increases, more WO3 is produced on the FTO, leading to improved catalytic performance, but a thicker WO3 film would increase the electron transfer paths, which could decrease the catalytic performance. Therefore, a hydrothermal time of 3 h is optimized for the synthesis of WO3. The presence of excess Ov on the surface corresponds to the loss of electrons in the bonding orbitals of the valence band, which weakens the chemical bonds between neighbouring atoms and makes these atoms susceptible to dissolution from the solid by interacting with affinity reagents in electrolyte [28]. Therefore, it is necessary to regulate the amount of Ov. LSV experiments were carried out on WO3, WO3- x -6 h, WO3- x -9 h, and WO3- x -12 h photoanodes to evaluate their photocatalytic performance for OER. As shown in Fig. 3(a), the chopped LSV curves clearly show that under AM 1.5 G illumination, the WO3- x -9 h photoanode exhibits a significantly higher photocurrent density (up to 1.89 mA cm−2 at 0.6 V vs. Ag/AgCl) compared to that of the pristine WO3 (up to 1.08 mA cm−2 at 0.6 V vs. Ag/AgCl). However, after increasing the hydrothermal time to 12 h, the photocurrent density of WO3- x -12 h decreases to 1.74 mA cm−2 (0.6 V vs. Ag/AgCl). The OCP curve shows that the WO3- x -9 h photoanode delivers a much lower OCP than that of WO3- x -6 h and WO3- x -12 h photoanodes in the three-electrode system (Fig. S7). This suggests that a suitable amount of Ov is introduced after 9 h of hydrothermal reduction treatment, which is beneficial for interfacial charge transfer and inhibition of photogenerated electron-hole recombination. In contrast, a long reduction time (12 h) may produce an excess of Ov that subsequently acts as a trap site for electron-hole recombination [29]. The chopped LSV curves of the photoanodes have little transient spikes when the light is turned on (positive spikes) or off (negative spikes), indicating that holes are transferred to the surface of the photoanode for catalyzing OER at the semiconductor/electrolyte interface rather than accumulating in the trap state [14]. Mott-Schottky plots show that the flat band potential of the WO3 photoanode is slightly negatively shifted when Ov is introduced. The band edge shift caused by Ov may contribute to the charge transfer efficiency [30], and the positive slope indicates that both WO3 and WO3- x are n-type semiconductors (Fig. S8). To understand the interfacial electron transfer kinetics during OER, EIS curves for WO3, WO3- x -6 h, WO3- x -9 h, and WO3- x -12 h were measured under AM 1.5 G illumination with an applied bias potential of 0 V (vs. Ag/AgCl). As shown in Fig. 3 (b), the impedance profiles of the four electrodes contain only a single semicircular curve, indicating that the charge transfer process acts as a rate-determining step during OER for all photoanodes within the tested frequencies. The semicircle in the frequency region represents the transport of charges at the interface between the material surface and the electrolyte, and the small radius of the semicircle represents a more rapid transport of charges [32,33]. The inset shows the equivalent circuit, where R ct represents the charge transfer resistance, R s is the series resistance and CPE is the constant phase element [31]. Obviously, the pristine WO3 has the largest impedance arc radius. In contrast, WO3- x -9 h has the smallest impedance arc radius and, as can be seen from Table S2, the smallest charge transfer resistance value, which indicates the smallest charge transfer impedance and therefore WO3- x -9 h has the fastest charge transfer kinetics among these photoanodes. The externally biased solar energy conversion efficiency (ABPE) is one of the indicators used to evaluate the performance of the photoanode and is derived from the effect of externally applied currents by abating the solar energy conversion efficiency. The ABPE of the photoanode can be calculated using Eq. (2). (2) A B P E ( % ) = ( J × ( 1.23 - V b ) / P t o t ) × 100 % Where J is the photocurrent density at the applied bias (mA cm−2), V b is the applied bias (V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode), and P tot is the power density of the incident light (mW cm−1). Fig. 3(c) shows the ABPE diagrams of the WO3, WO3- x -6 h, WO3- x -9 h, and WO3- x -12 h photoanodes. The ABPE values for WO3, WO3- x -6 h, WO3- x -9 h, and WO3- x -12 h photoanodes are 0.23%, 0.31%, 0.38%, and 0.35% at 0.22 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), respectively. The higher the ABPE value, the higher the applied potential needed to reach the maximum value and the better the performance of the photoanode [34]. Therefore, WO3- x -9 h with an ABPE of 0.38% exhibits superior performance for photoelectrochemical OER. Finally, a shutter controller shielded/unshielded light was used as chopped illumination to test the anodic response and long-term stability, with the shielded/unshielded time held at 30 s (Fig. 3d). The WO3- x photocurrent density remains at 95% of the initial value after 10 h of photo-switching cycles, indicating the excellent stability of the photoanode. As shown in Fig. S9, The WO3 shows a stable photocurrent density of ca. 0.15 mA cm−2, which is significantly lower than that of WO3- x , and the photocurrent density remains 84% of the initial value after 10 h of photoswitching cycles, which exhibits relatively poor stability compared to the WO3- x photoanode. Furthermore, the magnified inset shows that the WO3- x photoanode rapidly responds to the visible light. The shielded/unshielded time was kept at 30 s and the WO3- x semiconductor photoelectrodes were characterized by XPS and EPR after 10 h of optical switching cycling. As shown in Fig. S10, after 10000 s of testing, the XPS and EPR data indicate a reduction in the OV content of WO3- x after the testing. Photocorrosion of n-type semiconductors manifests itself as the dissolution of the anode, and the rate-determining step of the dissolution always uses holes as the reactant. Photo-oxidative coupled dissolution depends primarily on the relative rates of photocorrosion, interfacial charge transfer, and surface complexation rates [35]. Therefore, photocorrosion can be kinetically inhibited when the rate of interfacial charge transfer or surface complexation is higher than that of photocorrosion. Na2SO3, an effective hole scavenger, which can be oxidized very quickly at the semiconductor-electrolyte interface, is often used to assess the degree of charge separation [36]. The photocurrent generated by Na2SO3 oxidation is shown in Fig. S11. The surface separation efficiency of WO3 and WO3- x is further assessed by adding Na2SO3 as a hole scavenger to the Tris-PBS electrolyte (Fig. 3e). The high charge transfer efficiency obtained on the WO3- x photoanode shows an improvement in the OER kinetics due to the increased Ov on the surface. Surface Ov can significantly improve charge carrier separation efficiency by migrating the valence band edge of WO3 to a more unfavorable position. Thus, the increased charge carrier separation efficiency effectively suppresses the anode photocorrosion. Fig. 3(f) shows the concentration of dissolved W ions before and after stability tests. The concentration of W ions dissolved from WO3- x is much lower than that of pristine WO3, demonstrating that the introduction of Ov significantly suppresses the photocorrosion of WO3. 3.3 Characterization and electrochemical performance of the BOD/PIX/CNTs biocathode BOD was used as biocatalyst for ORR [37,38]. To further increase the catalytic performance, PIX was utilized as an orientation agent to facilitate direct electron transfer (DET) between the active site of BOD and the electrode surface [39]. Fig. S12 shows the molecular structure of PIX. The strong π-π interaction between PIX and CNTs, and the electrostatic interaction between PIX and BOD could enhance the stability of the biocathode and allow fast DET via the shortest pathway (compared to the other disordered orientation of the BOD (Fig. S13), thus improving the ORR kinetics [40]. Fig. S14 shows SEM images of CC/CNTs and CC/CNTs/PIX. CNTs are approximately 50–60 nm in diameter and exhibit an overlapping mesh structure, which is beneficial for enzyme loading and provides multiple channels for electron transfer. The PIX/CNTs composite maintains an excellent three-dimensional configuration, with reduced gaps between the CNTs and some of the tubes glue together due to the presence of π-π interaction between PIX and CNTs. To examine the superiority of the BOD-modified biocathode versus the commercial Pt/C for catalyzing ORR, the LSV curves of the BOD/CNTs biocathode and Pt/C cathode in 0.1 M Tris-PBS buffer (pH 7.0) were tested. As shown in Fig. S15(a), no ORR currents can be detected for the two cathodes in an oxygen-free environment. When the electrolyte is saturated with O2, the BOD/CNTs biocathode and the commercial Pt/C cathode both exhibit ORR currents. Note that the onset potential of ORR for the BOD/CNTs biocathode is 0.54 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), much higher than that of the commercial Pt/C cathode (0.18 V vs. Ag/AgCl), indicating that the BOD/CNTs biocathode has much lower overpotential for catalyzing ORR at neutral condition. No ORR current is observed in the CV plots of PIX/CNTs in the presence and absence of O2 (Fig. S15b), proving that the ORR current originated from BOD catalysis. A series of electrochemical performance tests were carried out to demonstrate that the electrostatic interaction between PIX and BOD improves the ORR performance of BOD. Fig. 4 (a) presents the LSV curve of the BOD/CNTs biocathode in 0.1 M Tris-PBS buffer (pH 7.0). The BOD/CNTs biocathode has no ORR current in an oxygen-free environment. When the electrolyte is saturated with O2, the BOD/CNTs biocathode exhibits an ORR current. The ORR onset potential of the BOD/CNTs biocathode is 0.54 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), and the maximum cathodic reduction current is 0.32 mA cm−2. In addition, the ORR current decreases when the electrode potential reaches 0.4 V, indicating that the slow O2 transport in solution limits the ORR at the electrode surface [41]. Fig. 4(b) shows the LSV curves of the BOD/PIX/CNTs biocathode in 0.1 M Tris-PBS buffer (pH 7.0). No ORR current is observed in an oxygen-free environment. In contrast, a high ORR current can be detected when the electrolyte is saturated with O2. It is worth noting that the ORR onset potential of the BOD/PIX /CNTs biocathode is 0.56 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), which is higher than that of the BOD/CNTs biocathode (0.54 V vs. Ag/AgCl), indicating that the introduction of PIX further decreases the ORR overpotential. In addition to a more positive ORR potential, the ORR current of the BOD/PIX/CNTs biocathode is significantly enhanced (0.58 mA cm−2), which is higher than that of the BOD/CNTs biocathode (0.32 mA cm−2). Once the peak current is reached, a gradual decrease in the current is also observed, indicating the limited O2 transport. Since the enzyme activity would be affected by the pH of the supporting electrolyte [42–44], the CV curves of the BOD/PIX/CNTs cathodes were tested in 0.1 M Tris-PBS at different pH. As shown in Fig. S16, the ORR onset potential of the BOD/PIX/CNTs shifts towards a more negative potential as the pH increases and a maximum ORR current value of 0.58 mA cm−2 can be obtained at pH 7.0. The catalytic ORR current drops sharply in either over-acidic or over-basic electrolytes. Therefore, 0.1 M Tris-PBS at pH 7.0 is optimized as an electrolyte. To further reveal the ORR kinetics of the BOD/CNTs and BOD/PIX/CNTs biocathodes, rotating disc electrodes were used to investigate the ORR behaviour of BOD/CNTs and BOD/PIX/CNTs at different rotational speeds [45]. As shown in Fig. S17, the ORR currents for both biocathodes increase with the increase of speeding rate, indicating that the mass transfer of O2 from the solution accelerates with the increase of speeding rate. The BOD/CNTs modified electrode does not reach the diffusion-limited current at a potential of 0 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) (Fig. S17a), demonstrating its slow ORR kinetics. Fig. S17(b) shows that the BOD/PIX/CNTs modified electrode reaches a diffusion-limited current of 2.71 mA cm−2 at a correct potential at 2025 r min−1, demonstrating its excellent ORR activity. Kentucky-Levich curves were obtained using LSV data at different speeding rates for BOD/CNTs and BOD/PIX/CNTs, as shown in Fig. S17(c and d). The fitted curves for BOD/PIX/CNTs present a near overlap, demonstrating that the ORR pathway at the electrode surface maintains a first-order reaction kinetics with the amount of dissolved oxygen in the electrolyte and does not change with the applied potential, and the ORR pathway undergoes a similar number of electron transfers at different potentials. Fig. 4(c) shows the potential range from 0 to 0.4 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), corresponding to the peroxide yield and the number of electrons transferred during ORR at BOD/CNTs and BOD/PIX/CNTs modified electrodes. The disc electrode was subjected to a potential negative scan (0.7–0 V) at the same scan rate, while the ring potential was kept constant at 1.0 V (vs. Ag/AgCl). The percentage of H2O2 production (ω%) and the number of electron transfers ( n ) were determined by the following Eqs. (3) and (4). (3) ω % = 200 × I r / N I d + I r / N (4) n = 4 × I r / N I d + I r / N Where I d is the disk current, I r is the ring current, and N is the current collection efficiency of the Pt ring. N = 0.40 determined from the reduction of K3Fe[CN]6. The peroxide yield is below 1.5% for the BOD/PIX/CNTs modified electrode and below 6% for the BOD/CNTs modified electrode. The electron transfer numbers are close to 4 for both electrodes, indicating that the ORR pathway catalyzed by the BOD/CNTs and BOD/PIX/CNTs modified electrodes mainly is a 4e− reduction step. Finally, the stability of the BOD/PIX/CNTs modified electrode was evaluated. As shown in Fig. 4(d), no ORR current is observed in the initial N2-saturated environment. When O2 gas is bubbled into the electrolyte, a sharp increase in ORR current can be detected. The steady-state current at the BOD/PIX/CNTs modified electrode is 2.4 mA cm−2. After 10 h of testing, the steady-state current of the BOD/PIX/CNTs modified electrode is decreased to 2.25 mA cm−2, and a current retention rate of 93.75% is obtained, indicating that the BOD/PIX/CNTs modified electrode has good stability. 3.4 Performance evaluation of the assembled BPECs In order to test whether the water/oxygen circulation system described above can be achieved, a closed photoelectrochemical cell was selected to implement the discharge pathway for BPECs. As shown in Fig. 5 (a and b), the cell is fabricated using WO3- x /FTO as photoanode, BOD/PIX/CNTs/CC as biocathode, and 0.1 M Tris-PBS (pH 7.0) as electrolyte. The specific operation principle of the BPECs can be described as follows. Upon illumination, the photogenerated holes can migrate to the WO3- x surface to catalyze OER, while the photogenerated electrons transfer to BOD/PIX/CNTs/CC via an external circuit. BOD within the biocathode receives the photogenerated electrons and catalyzes the reduction of the released O2 to H2O, thus completing the water/oxygen circulation [46]. Fig. S18 shows the OCP profiles for the WO3- x /FTO photoanode, BOD/PIX/CNTs/CC biocathode in the three-electrode system and BPEC under AM 1.5G illumination. The photoanode and biocathode can reach OCP of −0.26 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) and 0.56 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), respectively, and the BPEC reaches an open circuit voltage of up to 0.81 V, indicating that the assembled BPEC can supply a sufficient amount of potential for practical applications. Fig. 5(c) shows the LSV curves of BPEC under different conditions. No current is generated in the absence of light. Under AM 1.5 G illumination, the BPECs deliver maximum current densities of 1.08 mA cm−2 and 1.62 mA cm−2 at 0 V in air and oxygen-saturated electrolyte, respectively, indicating that the oxygen concentration significantly affects the performance of the BPECs [47]. To further evaluate the performance of the assembled BPECs, the power output and cell voltage as a function of current density were tested under AM 1.5G irradiation. As shown in Fig. 5(d and e), the maximum power output densities produced by the BPECs in air- and oxygen-saturated electrolyte are 245 μW cm−2 (at 0.39 V) and 283 μW cm−2 (at 0.35 V), respectively. The stability and photo-response performance of the BPECs under intermittent light were examined using the chronoamperometric method with the automatic shielding/unshielded gap of 60 s. As seen in Fig. 5(f and g), the BPEC exhibits a fast response to visible light and quickly reaches a steady-state current. The long-term stability test of 36000 s reveals that there is almost no change in current density from the initial value under oxygen-saturated conditions, with a retention rate of 97% of the original power density. The result demonstrates the successful construction of robust BPECs and the ability to convert multiple energy sources (light and chemical) into electricity. Under sealed and continuous illumination conditions, the discharge curve decreases in the beginning 100 s and reaches a steady-state current, with final power retention of 96% after 10 h of discharge (Fig. S19). At the beginning of the light-driven cell under nitrogen-saturated condition, a small amount of O2 is produced by the WO3- x catalyzed OER, and the generated O2 cannot be fully supplied to the BOD/PIX/CNTs/CC cathode, so the ORR pathway of the cathode is greatly restricted, which results in a decrease in discharge power (Fig. S19b). With the progress of catalytic OER at the WO3- x photoanode, the O2 release from the photoanode is sufficient, and a dynamic equilibrium is maintained (where the reaction rates of the photoanode and biocathode are maintained at a certain level), resulting in a stable discharge power, and thus the water/oxygen circulation can be completed under illumination. The storage stability of the assembled BPECs is investigated. As shown in Fig. 5(h and i), the discharge current of the BPECs on the first day reaches 0.44 mA cm−2. After 240 h of storage, the discharge current is still retained at 0.24 mA cm−2, with a current retention rate of 55%. The result shows that the BOD modified biocathode is stable in this environment for a long time. This work demonstrates the superior performance among the previously reported literature (Table S3) and indicates that the as-fabricated BPECs are promising in practical use. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a facile one-step hydrothermal reduction strategy is proposed to prepare WO3- x photoanode for photoelectrocatalytic OER in BPECs application. The EG thermal reduction method can produce Ov on the WO3 surface in a controlled manner, which improves the charge separation efficiency, OER kinetics, and structural stability. The BOD-modified biocathode with better ORR performance is prepared by an induced orientation method using CNTs as the electrode material and PIX as the orientation inducer. The introduction of PIX further decreases the ORR overpotential of the BOD-modified cathode, and the ORR current is significantly enhanced. A fuel-free BPEC based on a self-circulation system is assembled using WO3- x as photoanode, BOD/PIX/CNTs-modified CC as biocathode, which delivers a high OCP of 0.81 V and maximum output power of up to 283 μW cm−2. The BPEC maintains 97% of its original power after long-term stability testing (36000 s). Sealing tests demonstrate that the water/oxygen circulation can be achieved entirely in a fuel-free model with excellent storage stability (0.24 mA cm−2 after 240 h of storage, with a current retention rate of 55%). This work sheds light on the rational design of robust WO3 photoanode with enhanced catalytic properties and long-term stability in BPECs application, which may guide future designs for high-performance photoelectrodes and green energy conversion devices. coredata.dc:description: Bio-photoelectrochemical cells (BPECs) can further expand the use of conventional biofuel cells for renewable energy, but the poor stability of the photoelectrode still hinders their practical application. Herein, a BPEC capable of long-term operating in a fuel-free model is fabricated by WO3- x photoanode with oxygen vacancy (Ov) and bilirubin oxidase catalyzed biocathode. The construction of Ov on the WO3 surface significantly suppresses the dissolution of W species into the electrolyte, and improves the charge separation efficiency and the reaction kinetics during the photoelectrochemical oxygen evolution process, thus enhancing the stability and power output performance of the BPEC. As a result, the assembled BPEC can output an open circuit voltage of 0.81 V and deliver a maximum output power of up to 283 μW cm−2. Impressively, the BPECs maintain 97% of their original power after 36000 s of consecutive discharge under an enclosed environment. This fuel-free BPEC based on a robust WO3- x photoanode shows excellent promise for accurate application.
